firstthought: The Federal income taxes that have to be paid annually. I also think how irresponsible Congress can be with taxpayers money! I wish Congress would consider all of the very hard working taxpayers when they throw around OUR money!
recent: We tax at least once a week in the form of state sales tax. We also pay our federal taxes annually. I wish more people felt this obligation since I know that there are people who little or no tax that should be paying.
tpfeel: I guess I'd say that we're proud that we're helping to support our nation.
glad: I'm very glad that our tax dollars are paying for medical advances. I'm also glad that our money pays to support people who are truly disabled and to the help the elderly with Social Security Income. Our vast highway system is thanks to federal government expenditures as well as dams and many of our bridges. Our federal government itself is supported by taxpayer dollars and I'm very happy to live in this democratic society.
upset: It really upsets me when people cheat the government by fraudulently collecting welfare money. One thing that is the most upsetting is the following example: there was a woman who had just had her NINTH child when my children were in grade school. She was on welfare and would've been collecting all the various monies associated with welfare and having young children. Possibly the worst thing about this woman having babies for income was how these children were cared for, or lack of care. I was invited to the place where they lived, an old trailer with one rocking chair, and a wobbly table. The woman opened up the pantry and there were DOZENS of cans of tuna!! She also seemed proud of the fact that she had rented her house and was living in this firetrap for free. She told me that she had just spent $100 on socks for the kids! This was 30 years ago so that was an extraordinary amount of money to spend for that.
benefit: We benefit anytime we drive on a highway, go over one of the many bridges we have in our city, and many other ways.
wastethink: Well, well, well, don't get me started! Some of the corporate bailouts were a disaster. Some kind of controls should've been associated with the bailouts so the corporate ceo's didn't leave with millions of taxpayers money in bonuses.

firstthought: If they are going up, then I'm in deep financial trouble.  If they are being reduced, that may be great depending on the circumstances and fine print.
recent: A few days ago when I went grocery shopping I was taxed on my food purchases.
tpfeel: Sometimes (as in grocery shopping) I get aggravated due to all the tax charged on food items, but for the most part I feel like a responsible, legal American citizen paying their dues.
biggest: It's most likely a toss up between the real estate taxes on my house and our food budget (my husband eats a lot).
paystub: Wages, taxes & tips followed by social security, state income tax, federal income tax.
glad: That's a tough question.  I don't have children (so education is out), rarely drive (infrastructure improvements, which there are very little of, are out), possibly the Sheriff's Department and hopefully when I'm ready to retire - my social security.
upset: Education and school improvements (I have never had children, yet I'm paying taxes for everyone else's children to benefit) a local police force (not the County Sheriff's Department) that can't seem to catch the psycho that tried to kill me 15 years ago & is still harassing & stalking me.  I'm not as upset about funding going to welfare and other public programs, I just wish recipients were made to have drug screenings like the rest of us when we apply for a job so my taxes aren't paying for folks to birth babies and sit on their asses all day long collecting a free paycheck.  I'm upset that my tax dollars pay for local officials to go on special trips to supposedly "investigate" things or go to seminars.  I think that's a load of bunk.
benefit: Yes.  When I was first laid off from my job I was allowed to collect some unemployment funding to assist with paying my bills until I could obtain other employment.
wastethink: Overseas trips for "special" purposes, junkets to Las Vegas for conferences, high government salaries for the few rotten apples that do not do their jobs in the first place and buying overpriced items just because the government has to utilize special contractors from whom to purchase items.

firstthought: Salar deductions; community services
recent: Last year I paid tax on back pay of social security disability payments.  This year I will not likely pay taxes on my disability payments.
tpfeel: Responsible, Adult, Patriotic.  I paid taxes for decades before becoming disabled by illness and had no qualms about my taxes paying for social programs because I feel that this is the mark of a civilized society.   Now that I need those social programs I appreciate these tax-funded programs even more, they are the difference between life and death for me.
biggest: I pay a lot in property taxes, but now that I am disabled I'm not required to pay taxes on SSDI income.
glad: Community services like police, fire dept., ambulance; Social Security and Medicare; Food Stamps/SNAP; other social programs that help low-income people; public education; Federal government; FTC, FCC, FBI, Credit Protection Bureau, courts; road maintenance; unemployment benefits; FDIC bank protection; NTSB; FAA
upset: Too much military action and weaponry; too many redundant security agencies (NSA, CIA, Homeland Security); corporate bailouts and tax-breaks; too many administrative costs for politicians and too many perks for congressional reps.
benefit: Yes.  I once had to call police to come to my house, and when I used to volunteer on a local fire dept. we depended on tax money to fund our equipment and training.  I now depend on Social Security for disability income after becoming too ill to work.  I also qualify for some Food Stamps funding which is paid for through taxes, but still don't have enough money for food, so any further cuts to SNAP will mean more days without food for me.
wastethink: The salaries we pay to Congress comes to mind....  Also, duplication of efforts by NSA, CIA, FBI, and Homeland Security.  Mostly, the tax dollars that go to too many administrator salaries.
eitcexp: The EIC meant I paid less in taxes that year, which helped because I was only able to work part-time due to increased illness, and was struggling to keep up with bills.  It didn't make a huge difference, but it was better than nothing.  It meant a few months of adequate food money in my budget.
eitcthink: I think it is the bare minimum that needs to be done to help people in need.  Revoking it would be evil.

firstthought: The price we pay for civilization.
recent: There would've been sales tax on my lunch.
tpfeel: It's just a fact of life, not really good or bad. I'm proud to be a citizen, and I think it's my moral duty to contribute to support our society, but it's the identity of "citizen" I care about, not "taxpayer".
biggest: I think federal income tax is our largest, but I'm not certain; FICA is non-trivial, especially if you count the employer share, and sales taxes are pretty steep in CA as well..
paystub: Federal Income, Federal OASDI, Medicare, State Income, State OASDI
glad: General social safety net (OASDI, various medical insurance programs, SNAP), investment in infrastructure, scientific and medical research, education, management of the macro-economy, public health and safety, maintaining public parks and monuments, lots of other stuff.
upset: Wasteful military spending, subsidizing religion (especially lies in the schools, like "abstinence only" sex ed), war on drugs, over-aggressive surveillance, probably other things I could think of.
benefit: Yes. The basic infrastructure of society depends on taxes. Without taxes there can be no State, and without a State, you live in the state of nature, in which life is nasty, brutish, and short.  You're at the mercy of whoever wants to come along and kill you or take your stuff.  I got a pretty good public K-12 education, depend on public roads and trains to get to work, work in an industry that wouldn't exist without the public investment that created computers and the internet, benefit from many medical advances that were at least in part paid for by government funds, etc.
wastethink: Pentagon bloat.
eitcthink: I'd be in favor of expanding the EITC to subsidize the employment of people at the bottom of the skills ladder.  I'm lukewarm on the child credit as it exists; I'd rather convert the deductions for children into refundable credits, making them more valuable to poor people, less valuable to rich people.

firstthought: The price we all must pay for the services that our communities need.

depend: We claim two, my husband and myself.

upset: I do not like the huge amount of taxes that goes toward the military/industrial budget, I do not think that military response is the best way to handle most problems and the military is probably the most wasteful segment of our government.
benefit: Of course, communities are like families. We all contribute what we are able to support the community and its members and so the community is stronger for everyone.

glad: I am glad my tax dollars pay for road repair and cleanup (in the winter), for federal and state agencies that work for the public good (disease prevention, airport security, clean air and water, etc.), and to funds libraries and other centers of learning.
upset: I am not happy that my taxes are paying for welfare programs, healthcare, government patronage positions and aid for foreign countries.
benefit: I have benefited from State and Federal taxes which pay for infrastructure improvements, public education and other programs.  I have been allowed to drive from paying a Motor Vehicle licensing tax.
wastethink: Prices that have been inflated because 'the government' is buying something, like vests for military personnel.

firstthought: Money out of my pocket. My taxes have increased in the past year. Too much taxpayer's money is wasted on programs for which there is too much waste and too little oversight/accountability.
recent: Yesterday, at the grocery store. I paid sales tax of 9%.
tpfeel: I know we need taxes to support government expenditures, but there is too much waste in government and too little accountability to the taxpayer for the money that is spent. Taxpayer dollars are needed for defense spending, infrastructure, and Medicare/Medicaid, etc. but the government has become too bloated and intrusive.
paystub: Federal income tax, social security, Medicare, state tax. My husband also pays a 1% occupational tax because he works within the city limits.
glad: Defense spending. Highways and roads. The Department of Homeland Security. The Department of Veteran's Affairs. HHS. The Department of Justice, including the federal courts and Supreme Court. The Secret Service, the Federal Reserve Banks, etc. Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, etc. SNAP, except that it's so abused. I'm sure there's more if I thought about it long enough.
upset: Department of Education. A bloated federal government. Pensions, goodies, and benefits for life for Congressional representatives and Senators. I'm mad that there's no oversight of huge programs that are being abused, like WIC and SNAP.
benefit: I benefit from the highways I drive on (infrastructure) although there are some areas that still need work. I benefit from defense spending. I benefit from the sales taxes collected in my area that fund the local schools, even though we don't have kids, because it's good for the resale value of our home to be in a good school system. I may/may not benefit from Social Security and Medicare when the time comes. The programs may be bankrupt.
wastethink: Too many Federal departments and programs, e.g. Dept. of Education (among others). This should be up to the local governments, not the federal government. Too little oversight of programs that are rife with abuse and fraud, such as WIC and SNAP. I'm an interpreter, and have seen firsthand the incredible fraud and abuse that goes on in these programs in my area. Multiply that on a national level, and we're talking at least tens of millions of dollars. There's no one overseeing these programs for fraud and abuse.
